The Annenberg Foundation for the Arts (AFTA) in Los Angeles announced today that it is creating a new $3.8 million endowment for the preservation and future care of the artifacts in its collection. The $3.8 million will fund preservation and future education initiatives as well as partnerships with universities and state and local governments.“The Annenberg Foundation is committed to supporting all those who have made significant contributions to American art and to ensuring that the collection and exhibitions of the Annenberg Collection are enhanced and maintained through the future,” said John Baldessari, president of the foundation. “The gift of these objects and the gift of their collections, artifacts, exhibitions, and programs is an amazing opportunity for the Foundation to become a meaningful and enduring voice for the art of the Americas. Our work will be carried out in harmony with the collective vision of the entire community, and in recognition of the contributions of our predecessors and many of those who have passed in their years of accomplishment.”The new partnership with AFTA will focus on preservation and future education initiatives that are centered around the work of Women Artists and will be led by AFTA artistic director Rebecca Wilk. The Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, DC, has appointed Katherine Lewis as its next director. Lewis comes to the institution from the New Museum, where she has served as interim director since April 2019. During her tenure at the New Museum, she transformed the museum into a more than 130-year-old arts complex, expanded college admissions, introduced studio classes, and expanded the collection.“Throughout her tenacious work to shape the Hirshhorn into what it is today, Katherine has been an inspired leader and a joy to work alongside,” said New Museum director Christopher Bedford. “Her conviction to see the Hirshhorn Museum thrive and thrive and flourish, her passion and her ability to motivate and motivate her staff, and her ability to create and deliver exciting exhibitions and programs in an engaging and challenging environment, combined with her ability to collaborate with renowned curators, writers, and scholars, has always been at the core of what makes the Hirshhorn Museum great.”Lewis will assume her new responsibilities on June 6.

On November 18, the Museo de Arte Contemporáneo (MAS) in Lisbon announced that it will prepare for the return of the Portuguese master, José Pires, whose work was heavily influenced by his homeland, but was later in the country exiled for his political views. The exhibition, “Pires’ Legacy,” will highlight the work of thirty-one of Pires’s works in the city of Lisbon, along with the history of his studio.The twenty-fifth edition of the exhibition, “Pires: From Moment to Moment” will be held at the Museo Nacional Nacional in Lisbon from January 20 to February 24, 2024. The exhibition will also feature works by contemporary artists, including inventors, creators, and activists. The inaugural exhibition is curated by artist-in-residence Anna-Kaisa Rocha, and is led by curator Joana Pape, who will serve as the curator of the exhibition.
